name: Java Arrays
description: Array declaration, initialization, manipulation, and multidimensional arrays in Java.

questions.title: Basic If Statement
questions.description: What is the output of this code?
questions.explanation: Since x (10) is greater than 5, the condition is true and "Greater" is printed.

questions.title: If-Else If Chain
questions.description: What is the output of this code?
questions.explanation: Score is 85, which is not >= 90 but is >= 80, so "B" is printed. Only the first matching condition executes.

questions.title: For Loop Basics
questions.description: How many times does this loop execute?
questions.explanation: The loop runs while i < 5. Starting from 0, it executes for i = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 (5 times total).

questions.title: While Loop
questions.description: What is the final value of count?
questions.explanation: The loop continues while count < 3. After incrementing 3 times (0→1, 1→2, 2→3), count becomes 3 and the loop stops.

questions.title: Do-While Loop
questions.description: How many times does this loop execute?
questions.explanation: Do-while loops execute at least once before checking the condition. Even though x (10) is not < 10, the loop body runs once.

questions.title: Switch Statement
questions.description: What is the output of this switch statement?
questions.explanation: The switch matches case 2, prints "Tuesday", and the break statement prevents fall-through to other cases.

questions.title: Switch Fall-Through
questions.description: What is the output when there's no break statement?
questions.explanation: Without break statements, execution falls through all subsequent cases. Starting from case 1, it prints "One Two Three".

questions.title: Break Statement
questions.description: What does the break statement do in a loop?
questions.explanation: The break statement immediately exits the loop. When i equals 5, the loop terminates, so only 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 are printed.

questions.title: Continue Statement
questions.description: What does the continue statement do?
questions.explanation: The continue statement skips the rest of the current iteration. When i equals 2, it skips the print statement and continues with i = 3.

questions.title: Nested Loops
questions.description: How many times is "Hello" printed?
questions.explanation: The outer loop runs 3 times, and for each iteration, the inner loop runs 2 times. Total: 3 × 2 = 6 times.

questions.title: Enhanced For Loop
questions.description: What does this enhanced for loop do?
questions.explanation: The enhanced for loop (for-each) iterates through array elements, printing each value: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

questions.title: Switch with Strings
questions.description: Can switch statements work with String values?
questions.explanation: Since Java 7, switch statements support String values. This code matches "apple" and prints "Red".

questions.title: Infinite Loop
questions.description: Which of these creates an infinite loop?
questions.explanation: All three constructs create infinite loops: for(;;) has no termination condition, while(true) and do-while(true) have always-true conditions.

questions.title: Loop Variable Scope
questions.description: What happens when you try to access the loop variable outside the loop?
questions.explanation: The loop variable 'i' is only in scope within the for loop. Accessing it outside the loop causes a compilation error.

questions.title: Switch Default Case
questions.description: When is the default case executed in a switch statement?
questions.explanation: The default case executes when none of the specified cases match the switch expression. Here, x=10 doesn't match any case, so "Other" is printed.

questions.title: Labeled Break
questions.description: What does a labeled break statement do?
questions.explanation: A labeled break exits the loop with the specified label. 'break outer' exits the outer loop entirely, not just the inner loop.

questions.title: If Without Braces
questions.description: What is the output of this code?
questions.explanation: Without braces, only the first statement belongs to the if. The second println always executes, so both "Positive" and "Number" are printed.

questions.title: Switch Expression (Java 14+)
questions.description: What is the value of result using switch expressions?
questions.explanation: Switch expressions (Java 14+) use arrow syntax and return values directly. For day=2, it returns "Tuesday".

questions.title: For Loop Variations
questions.description: Which for loop syntax is valid?
options: for (int i = 0, j = 10; i < j; i++, j--)
questions.explanation: All are valid: standard for loop, infinite loop with empty conditions, and multiple variable declarations/updates in a single for loop.

questions.title: While vs Do-While
questions.description: What's the key difference between while and do-while loops?
questions.explanation: While loops check the condition before executing (may not run at all), while do-while loops execute at least once before checking the condition.

questions.title: Switch with Enums
questions.description: Can switch statements work with enum values?
questions.explanation: Switch statements work well with enums. The case labels use the enum constant names without the enum type prefix.

questions.title: Nested If Statements
questions.description: What is the output of this nested if structure?
questions.explanation: x (10) > 5 is true, so we enter the outer if. Then y (20) > 15 is also true, so "Both conditions true" is printed.

questions.title: Loop Control with Return
questions.description: What happens when return is used inside a loop?
questions.explanation: The return statement exits the entire method immediately. It prints 0, 1, 2, then exits without printing "After loop".

questions.title: Switch Case Grouping
questions.description: What is the output when multiple cases share the same code block?
questions.explanation: Cases 12, 1, and 2 all fall through to the same code block. Since month=2, it matches case 2 and prints "Winter".

questions.title: For Loop with Collections
questions.description: What does this enhanced for loop print?
questions.explanation: The enhanced for loop iterates through the list. When it encounters "Bob", continue skips the print statement, so only "Alice" and "Charlie" are printed.

questions.title: Conditional Operator vs If
questions.description: What is equivalent to this if-else statement?
questions.explanation: The ternary operator (condition ? value1 : value2) is a concise way to write simple if-else assignments.

questions.title: Loop Performance
questions.description: Which loop structure is most efficient for iterating arrays?
questions.explanation: Modern JVMs optimize all these loop types similarly. The enhanced for loop is often preferred for readability, but performance differences are negligible.

questions.title: Switch Statement Limitations
questions.description: Which data types CANNOT be used in switch statements?
questions.explanation: Switch statements only work with byte, short, int, char, String (Java 7+), and enum types. float, double, boolean, and long are not supported.

questions.title: Loop Initialization
questions.description: What is the output of this for loop?
questions.explanation: The loop starts at i=5 and decrements. It prints 5, then 4, then when i becomes 3, the break statement exits the loop.

questions.title: Control Flow Best Practices
questions.description: Which is considered a best practice for control statements?
options: Always use braces even for single statements
Use meaningful variable names in loop conditions
questions.explanation: All are best practices: braces prevent errors when adding statements, avoiding deep nesting improves readability, and meaningful names make code self-documenting.
